Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Thunderstorm Coupling to the Lower Ionosphere through Electromagnetic, Acoustic, and Gravity Waves
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will quantify the impact on the ionosphere by thunderstorm activity through coupling from below in the form of lightning, acoustic waves, and gravity waves. Thunderstorms, lightning, and gravity waves are the primary known sources of coupling from the troposphere to the ionosphere and thermosphere, but their impacts are not well quantified. This program aims to quantify the effects of thunderstorms on the D-, E-, and F-regions of the ionosphere through electromagnetic, gravity, and acoustic waves. In particular, this program aims to address the effects of thunderstorm activity on sporadic-E layers, which are a dominant source of satellite-to-ground communication disruption. This program will utilize Very Low Frequency (VLF) narrowband and broadband data, together will optical measurements, to assess the impact of these sources on the D-region ionosphere and provide estimates of lightning-driven electric field magnitudes in the D- and E- regions. Simultaneously, GPS, ionosonde, radar, and optical observations will be used to assess the impacts of thunderstorm activity on the E- and F-regions. The Arecibo incoherent scatter radar and St. Croix coherent scatter radar will be used to assess thunderstorm effects on these ionospheric regions. Existing finite-difference and full-wave propagation models will be used to compare observations to theory. The Ph.D thesis of one graduate student will be supported by the program, and the data collected will be used by several other graduate students in the group. Data collected in this program will also be made available to the scientific community. Results of the program will benefit society through enhanced understanding of the interaction between tropospheric weather and space weather. The program will also enhance the scientific infrastructure at Arecibo and St. Croix through an advnaced photometer and VLF/LF receivers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on quantifying the effects of thunderstorms on the ionosphere. Those effects include heating of the ionosphere due to the electromagnetic fields created by thunderstorms and lightning, as well as the effects of atmospheric waves that are created by convection in thunderstorms. The electromagnetic fields of thunderstorms can directly heat the lower ionosphere and create new ionization; the atmospheric waves take much longer to reach the ionosphere, but may carry energy and momentum from the troposphere and dump it in the upper atmosphere. 

The intellectual merit of this work can be found in the many publications produced in the last few years. Early in the project, we discovered that acoustic and gravity waves could be observed by very-low-frequency (VLF) subionospheric remote sensing, which provides a measure of the activity in the lowest part of the ionosphere (the D-region). These waves were observed directly above a powerful squall-line type of thunderstorm; we modeled both the atmospheric waves and the VLF signal to estimate the force required in the thunderstorm, and found that this was likely a rare observation [Marshall and Snively, 2014, GRL]. 

Other work focused on the electromagnetic effects of lightning, including heating, ionization, and optical emissions known as elves. We were able to use elve observations from the ground, together with a global lightning dataset known as GLD360, to estimate the total number of elves produced around the world, and in turn the total heating of the lower ionosphere by lightning [Blaes et al, 2016, JGR]. As a novel side project, we also showed that elves could be used to estimate properties of the lightning discharge that are otherwise impossible to observe, such as the speed of current pulse along the lightning channel [Blaes et al, 2014]. We furthermore looked at the effect of lightning heating the ionosphere and its effect on the transmission of these electromagnetic waves into the Earth's magnetosphere [Marshall, 2014, JGR]. 

We next turned our attention to the idea that thunderstorms can hold the ionosphere in a heated state, even without lightning occurring. The charge distribution in the cloud produces electric fields that extend up to the ionosphere and create heating. When lightning occurs, it reconfigures this heated state, producing changes to the ionosphere that are observed in the VLF data [Kabirzadeh et al, 2017, JGR]. These results go against the favored mechanism to explain these VLF perturbations, and thus will remain controversial until they can experimentally verified or disproven. 

Most recently, our work has included modeling of X-ray and gamma-ray emissions by lightning. The recent discovery of terrestrial gamma-ray flashes (TGFs) observed in space has opened up a new field, and we are interested in assessing the effects of TGFs on the ionosphere and the space environment. We have modeled both the X-ray fluxes that can be observed on the ground related to lightning [Xu et al, 2017, JGR, in review], and we have predicted the heating and optical emissions that would be produced in the mesosphere by TGFs. These latter events constitute a new type of "transient luminous event", like sprites and elves, but again remain to be observed. 

The broader impacts of this project lie in the opportunities provided to young researchers to extend their training and experience in the space sciences. Dr. Robert Marshall began work on this program as a postdoctoral scholar at Stanford University, and thanks in part to this work, has gone on to be an Assistant Professor at the University of Colorado Boulder. The program further provided support to two graduate students at Stanford, Dr. Patrick Blaes (graduated in 2015) and Mr. Austin Sousa (defended July 2017, will graduate in December 2017). While Dr. Blaes has gone on to work in the high-tech industry in Silicon Valley, Mr. Sousa will continue as a postdoctoral scholar in this field. Finally, this project has provided support to Dr. Wei Xu at the University of Colorado Boulder, working as a postdoctoral scholar with Dr. Marshall. Dr. Xu has developed his expertise in numerical modeling of electromagnetic fields and X-ray production and propagation. His long-term goal is to find an tenure-track position at a research university. The opportunity provided by this project has helped him continue his training towards that goal.
